required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: High Flow Nasal Cannula in Patients Undergoing Ophthalmic Surgeries With Intravenous Sedation
clinical_study.official_title: High Flow Nasal Cannula in Patients Undergoing Ophthalmic Surgeries With Intravenous Sedation

lead_sponsor.agency: American University of Beirut Medical Center

clinical_study.source: American University of Beirut Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock:
High flow nasal cannula provides adequate oxygenation in patients with compromised pulmonary function. Very few studies in the literature addressed its use with IV sedation in the OR. Successful application of High Flow nasal cannula in intravenous deep sedation cases in the OR will benefit in the reduction of airway manipulation and side effects from general anesthesia.
This study aims to find out the optimal nasal cannula flow rate for maintenance of safe IV deep sedation in ophthalmic patients and to assess surgeon and patient satisfaction.

primary_outcome.description: The optimal flow rate stabilized for the patient which is determined by the oxygen saturation (%)

arm_group.description: High flow rate of 5 L/min and FiO2 of 40%
Nasal cannula at flow rate of 15 L/min and FiO2 of 40%
Nasal cannula at flow rate of 30 L/min and FiO2 of 40%
Nasal cannula at flow rate of 60 L/min and FiO2 of 40%

intervention.description: nasal cannula at a flow rate of 15 l/min and FiO2 of 40%
nasal cannula at a flow rate of 30l/min and FiO2 of 40%
nasal cannula at flow rate of 60L/min. Oxygen supplementation will be at an FiO2 of 40%.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Patient able to give consent.
2. Patient undergoing deep sedation.
3. Patient undergoing ophthalmic surgeries with no restrictions on the duration of the surgery.
4. Age > 18 years
5. Patients with BMI < 40 kg/m2
Exclusion Criteria:
1. patient unable to give consent
2. Patient refusal to participate
3. Patients undergoing general anesthesia
4. age less than 18 years old
5. Patients with severe heart failure (EF<30%)
6. Morbidly obese Patients with BMI > 40 kg/m2
7. Patients with sleep apnea
8. Claustrophobia
9. Risk of aspiration due to severe reflux
10. Facial injury, facial malformation
11. Nasal defects/obstruction

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: American University of Beirut Medical Center
